body:
@miraep8, unfortunately it is not an isolated issue ðŸ˜± 

the logs of your first run seem to have disappeared, do you remember anything from them?

on #2411, last life sign of `gw1`:

```
 utils/validation/tests/test_panel.py::test_check_X_bad_input_args[X1]

```

last life sign of `gw0`: 
```
2022-04-08T10:41:12.9206873Z [gw1] [ 57%] PASSED forecasting/tests/test_all_forecasters.py::TestAllForecasters::test_predict_time_index_in_sample_full[AutoEnsembleForecaster-int-int-True]

2022-04-08T10:41:12.9209825Z [gw0] [ 57%] PASSED forecasting/tests/test_all_forecasters.py::TestAllForecasters::test_update_predict_single[Prophet-update_params=True-fh=1]

2022-04-08T10:41:12.9211951Z forecasting/tests/test_all_forecasters.py::TestAllForecasters::test_predict_time_index_in_sample_full[AutoEnsembleForecaster-range-int-False] 
2022-04-08T10:41:12.9212754Z [gw1] [ 57%] PASSED forecasting/tests/test_all_forecasters.py::TestAllForecasters::test_predict_time_index_in_sample_full[AutoEnsembleForecaster-range-int-False]

2022-04-08T10:41:12.9214729Z [gw0] [ 57%] PASSED forecasting/tests/test_all_forecasters.py::TestAllForecasters::test_update_predict_single[Prophet-update_params=True-fh=[2 5]]

```

thatÂ´s ... `Prophet` ... why am I not surprised?

rename.to: [BUG] CI timeout on windows, python 3.7 - Facebook Prophet?

body: Yup, there's not much in the logs. My guess would be that one process hangs and hogs a lot of the resources and that slows down the other process. Might be worth to add a timeout https://github.com/pytest-dev/pytest-timeout but that will help us debug and not solve the issue. it seems to stalls on one of the _integration_ tests. As an alternative someone with a win machine could try to reproduce with docker and limiting the resources available to container.
yes, we should at least capture what test it was working on when it timed out - do you know how to add that? Simply adding the plugin and then the `--timeout=600` or so param?
Yep! I do still have them.  Its actually interesting - I am pretty sure that my code also failed at test_check_X_enforce_min columns. I will go grab the exact message

Here is the last few things that ran in the logs. Seems like that might be what is causing the issue? Just checked #2411 as well and that also seemed to be the failure point of earlier runs. 

`
[gw1] [ 93%] PASSED utils/validation/tests/test_panel.py::test_check_X_bad_input_args[X1] 
utils/validation/tests/test_panel.py::test_check_X_bad_input_args[X2] 
[gw1] [ 93%] PASSED utils/validation/tests/test_panel.py::test_check_X_bad_input_args[X2] 
utils/validation/tests/test_panel.py::test_check_X_bad_input_args[X3] 
[gw1] [ 93%] PASSED utils/validation/tests/test_panel.py::test_check_X_bad_input_args[X3] 
utils/validation/tests/test_panel.py::test_check_enforce_min_instances 
[gw1] [ 93%] PASSED utils/validation/tests/test_panel.py::test_check_enforce_min_instances 
utils/validation/tests/test_panel.py::test_check_X_enforce_univariate 
[gw1] [ 93%] PASSED utils/validation/tests/test_panel.py::test_check_X_enforce_univariate 
utils/validation/tests/test_panel.py::test_check_X_enforce_min_columns 
[gw1] [ 93%] PASSED utils/validation/tests/test_panel.py::test_check_X_enforce_min_columns 
Error: The operation was canceled.
`

An idea -  in addition to the timeout we could also print the 5 slowest tests?  I believe this can be done with the [--durations argument to pytest](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/27884404/printing-test-execution-times-and-pinning-down-slow-tests-with-py-test).  Though it is unclear how easy it is to recreate the error, this would make it easier to pinpoint the next time it happens?

Also - just fyi - I think if you click on the little red x next to the failed test then you are still able to access the details of the failed test! :)  That's how I got the logs!
![little_red_x](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/10511777/162847194-3f32d00e-e6d1-4eea-af8e-c57d0d356d2f.png)

issue.title: [ENH] add new argument return_tags to all_estimators

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:
<!--
Thanks for contributing a pull request! Please ensure you have taken a look
at our contribution guide: https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/blob/main/CONTRIBUTING.md
-->

#### Reference Issues/PRs
<!--
-->
Closes #2387


#### What does this implement/fix? Explain your changes.
<!--
-->
I have added a new argument 'return_tags' to the registry function all_estimators().  'return_tags' is an optional argument, either a str or list of str of tag names the user wants returned for all estimators returned.  If provided all_estimators will return each estimator's value for each tag in 'return_tags' or else None if the estimator doesn't have that tag.  I also added a new test to ensure all_estimators works if 'return_tags' is passed as a str or list of str. (the default - None is tested in other tests!)

#### Does your contribution introduce a new dependency? If yes, which one?

<!--
-->
No

#### What should a reviewer concentrate their feedback on?

<!-- 
 -->
Does this address the issue suggested?  Any test cases I should add?  Any other feedback?  (This is my first Pull Request so please let me know if I should be doing something differently!) 

#### Any other comments?
<!--
-->
Thank you for reviewing my PR!  Excited to be making my first contribution to sktime, hope this small change is useful! :)

#### PR checklist
<!--
Please go through the checklist below. Please feel free to remove points if they are not applicable.
-->

##### For all contributions
- [x] I've added myself to the [list of contributors](https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/blob/main/.all-contributorsrc).
- [ ] Optionally, I've updated sktime's [CODEOWNERS](https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/blob/main/CODEOWNERS) to receive notifications about future changes to these files.
- [x] I've added unit tests and made sure they pass locally.
- [x] The PR title starts with either [ENH], [DOC] or [BUG] indicating whether the PR topic is related to enhancement, documentation or bug


<!--
Thanks for contributing!
-->

body:
> Also - just fyi - I think if you click on the little red x next to the failed test then you are still able to access the details of the failed test! :)

Ah!!! Thanks for this learning moment. Did not know that clicking this got you somewhere.

rename.from: [BUG] CI timeout on windows, python 3.7 - Facebook Prophet?

body:
`test_check_X_enforce_min_columns` - that's really really odd.
I do not see anything in the test that could cause it to hang.

The log also seems strange - above it says that it PASSED, and then it says that it crashed?
Is this perhaps a mistake in `pytest-xdist` printout, and it is reporting the wrong test instance, i.e., not the one that hangs/crashes, but the one before?

>  in addition to the timeout we could also print the 5 slowest tests? 

I thought this was already printed? I always look at the end and the list is there, e.g., here: https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/issues/2377
Ah!  Makes a lot of sense!  Glad we have the source of the problem!  :)  I also was unsure why `test_check_X_enforce_min_columns` would cause this issue!

>I thought this was already printed? I always look at the end and the list is there, e.g., here: https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/issues/2377

Ah yes, I see now that the pytest is configured to print the time of each test on a successful test! :)  Would be nice if there was someway to access this information in the event of a timeout as well.

So, digging into the logs more:

as far as I now understand, each worker makes status updates in two steps: if a test is passed, it prints the `PASSED` message, and then it prints immediately the next test it starts to run.

So, in the log above, it would mean that `gw0` started `test_update_predict_single[Prophet-update_params=False-fh=1]` and got stuck there.

issue.title: [MNT] added pytest timeout of 5 minutes

labels.name: maintenance
labels.description: Continuous integration, unit testing & package distribution

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:
This PR adds a dependency on `pytest-timeout` in the `dev` dependency set, and a timeout-fail of 5min on all individual tests.

This will address tests hanging for 6 hours such as in https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/issues/2448 (they will fail earlier, at the 5min bound)
